A1.T1.caption: Table 1. General Terminology
A1.T1.table:
Term Meaning
FL Federated Learning.
GD Gradient Descent.
DCGD Distributed Compressed Gradient Descent.
TEE Trusted Execution Environments.
DP Differential Privacy.
MPC The term is overloaded. In the context of Federated Learning literature typically means Multi-Party Computation.
HE Homomorphic Encryption.
IoT The collective network of connected devices.
references: Our work is multidiscipline. To make our paper more readable for researchers with different backgrounds, we have constructed this Glossary.

A1.T2.caption: Table 2. Optimization Terminology
A1.T2.table:
Term Meaning
d𝑑d Dimension of optimization variable.
n𝑛n Number of clients/agents/devices.
fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} Local Loss function on client number i𝑖i.
f𝑓f Objective function with we want to minimize with image ℝℝ\mathbb{R} and domain ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}.
γ𝛾\gamma Step size of learning rate.
x𝑥x Trainable or Optimization variable from ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}.
xksuperscript𝑥𝑘x^{k} Trainable or Optimization variable at most outer loop of optimization algorithm number k𝑘k.
round The iteration in the outermost loop of the optimization algorithm.
eisubscript𝑒𝑖e_{i} The vector from ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} whose i-th component is equal 111 while all the others are zeros.
u.a.r. uniformly at random.
r.v. random variable.
p.d.f. probability distribution function.
𝔼[.]\mathbb{E}[.] Expectation of some Random Variable.
PermK Permutated correlated compressors.
Master Entity in FL which performs aggregation and other forms of reductions.

A1.T3.caption: Table 3. Discrete Math Terminology
A1.T3.table:
Term Meaning
Algebra Set of elements and defined operations on set which lead to elements of the same set.
Monoid Any algebra with the binary, associative operation, which also has a neutral element. Example - concatenation.
Group Any algebra with the binary, associative operation, with a neutral element and each element has an inverse.
Ring Algebra with summation, and multiplication. A summation is a commutative group, multiplication is a monoid. Multiplication is distributive with respect to summation. In Ring without extra assumptions can have a situation such that a≠0𝑎0a\neq 0, b≠0𝑏0b\neq 0, but a​b=0𝑎𝑏0ab=0.
Polynomial p​(x)=p0+p1⋅x+p2⋅x2+…𝑝𝑥subscript𝑝0⋅subscript𝑝1𝑥⋅subscript𝑝2superscript𝑥2…p(x)=p_{0}+p_{1}\cdot x+p_{2}\cdot x^{2}+\dots.
K​[x]𝐾delimited-[]𝑥K[x] Let K be some field. The set of all polynomials with coefficients in some field K𝐾K. It is called commutative called the polynomial ring over K𝐾K. In the Ring of polynomials K​[X]𝐾delimited-[]𝑋K[X] there is no division in general similar to Algebra N𝑁N. However, it’s possible to perform division with residual. One basis for such set is {1,x,x2,…}1𝑥superscript𝑥2…\{1,x,x^{2},\dots\}.
Z​[X]𝑍delimited-[]𝑋Z[X] Integer polynomial rings over commutative ring Z𝑍Z is denoted as Z​[X]𝑍delimited-[]𝑋Z[X]. This is the set of polynomials whose coefficients are integers and polynomials depend only on one variable.
P​[x]/(x2+1)𝑃delimited-[]𝑥superscript𝑥21P[x]/(x^{2}+1) This notation means polynomials which are obtained in the following way. We take the polynomial ring P​[x]𝑃delimited-[]𝑥P[x] and perform modulus division by the polynomial x2+1superscript𝑥21x^{2}+1. This modulus arithmetic restricts obtained polynomials to have a power less than 222. Such a ring is an example of a quotient ring.
Unity Roots Roots of unity are roots of the following equation Zn=1superscript𝑍𝑛1Z^{n}=1. If Z∈ℂ𝑍ℂZ\in\mathbb{C} the roots are: zk=exp⁡(2​π​k​i/n)subscript𝑧𝑘2𝜋𝑘𝑖𝑛z_{k}=\exp(2\pi ki/n) for k=0,1,2,…,n−1𝑘012…𝑛1k=0,1,2,\dots,n-1.
GCD The greatest common divisor (GCD) of two or more integers, that are not zero, is the largest positive integer that divides each of the integers. For example gcd⁡(8,12)=48124\gcd(8,12)=4.
     Homomorphism Homomorphism of two groups G1subscript𝐺1G_{1} and G2subscript𝐺2G_{2} is a mapping f:G1→G2:𝑓→subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2f:G_{1}\to G_{2} between two groups, such that ∀x,y∈G1for-all𝑥𝑦subscript𝐺1\forall x,y\in G_{1} the following holds: f​(x∗y)=f​(x)∗f​(y)𝑓𝑥𝑦𝑓𝑥𝑓𝑦f(x*y)=f(x)*f(y)
Isomomorphism Isomomorphism of groups G1subscript𝐺1G_{1} and G2subscript𝐺2G_{2} is a mapping f:G1→G2:𝑓→subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2f:G_{1}\to G_{2} between two groups, such ∀x,y∈G1for-all𝑥𝑦subscript𝐺1\forall x,y\in G_{1} the following holds: f​(x∗y)=f​(x)∗f​(y)𝑓𝑥𝑦𝑓𝑥𝑓𝑦f(x*y)=f(x)*f(y) and f𝑓f is bijection mapping. From the point of view of Algebraic structures, two isomorphic groups are the same, even if they have different natures of their elements.

A1.T4.caption: Table 4. Cryptography Terminology
A1.T4.table:
Term Meaning
FHE Fully Homomorphic Encryption.
SWHE Somewhat Homomorphic Encryption.
LFHE Leveled Fully Homomorphic Encryption.
CKKS Cheon-Kim-Kim-Song Homomorphic Encryption schema, which is formally only SWHE.
AES Advanced Encryption Standard.
sk Secret Key.
pk Public Key.
Symmetric Encryption Encryption schema in which secret and public key is the same.
PRP Pseudo Random Permutation.
PRF Pseudo Random Function.
MAC Message Authentication Code.
CRC Cyclic Redundancy Check.
CPA Chosen plaintext attack.
CCA Chosen ciphertext attack.
CTR Counter Mode Randomized.
CBC Cipher Block Chaining.
EAX Encrypt then Authenticate then Translate Mode.
LWE The Learning With Errors search problem to find a solution to a noisy system of linear equations in a finite field.
RLWE The Ring Learning With Errors search problem. Find a solution to a noisy system of the linear equation when an underlying algebra is a polynomial over a ring.
Integer Lattice It is a set of points which correspond to all possible linear combinations with integer coefficients of the n𝑛n vectors bi∈ℝdsubscript𝑏𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑b_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, i.e. it the set {x:x=∑i=1nαi​bi,αi∈ℤ}conditional-set𝑥formulae-sequence𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖subscript𝛼𝑖ℤ\{x:x=\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\alpha}_{i}b_{i},{\alpha}_{i}\in\mathbb{Z}\}.
references: In this type, all the nodes are connected to a central master device with individual links. In the case of using DCGD/PermK, the master in this topology only plays the role of communication hub. Interestingly, while obtaining parts of the gradients from clients, computation is unnecessary, and synchronization is far more relaxed, as we have observed in Appendix H.2. While using DCGD/PermK, the server can potentially utilize communication links with Full Duplex mode. Examples of Full Duplex communication buses include PCI-Express, InfiniBand777https://network.nvidia.com/pdf/whitepapers/HPC_Clustering_130.pdf, and some forms of Ethernet (see (Spurgeon, 2000) Table 4.1 in Chapter 4). In our setting, we consider the situation when clients are connected to the Internet, and as it has been described in Appendix H.2, PCI-Express is not a bottleneck. However, in data centers, PCI-Express can also represent a bottleneck (Li et al., 2019). With DCGD/PermK, during some period, a single link can be used simultaneously to obtain information from clients and deliver information to the clients. This is not the case for DCGD/RandK or GD because they require explicit synchronization. But it is the case for DCGD/PermK. This doubles the maximum bandwidth during master client communication and decreases latency by factor two.

A1.T5.table:
Term Meaning
DRAM Dynamic Random Access Memory.

     FP16, FP32, FP64 Float point format with a specified number of bits per single scalar.
CUDA Compute Unified Device Architecture.
CPU Central Processing Unit.
AVX Advanced Vector Extensions.
NIC Network Interface Controller.

A2.T6.caption: Table 6. Compared Optimization Algorithms with Compression and Privacy Mechanisms
A2.T6.table:
Name Description
1. GD [FP16|FP32|FP64] Algorithm 1, Baseline ( B), 𝒞i​(x)=defxsuperscriptdefsubscript𝒞𝑖𝑥𝑥\mathcal{C}_{i}(x)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}x.

Gradient Descend. In this algorithm, clients in a distributed way compute the gradient for the function fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} defined in Equation 2 in the current iterate. Master obtains gradients from the clients and averages them. The master broadcasts the result directly to all clients. The specified Floating-Point format is used to represent both data and trainable variables in all clients and during aggregation in the master.

Quantitative and qualitative characteristics: (1) It’s completely insecure (see Appendix E.1). (2) Volume information from clients to master is 𝒪​(d​n)𝒪𝑑𝑛\mathcal{O}(dn) bytes per round. (3) Broadcasted information from master to clients is 𝒪​(d)𝒪𝑑\mathcal{O}(d) bytes per round. For details on why information about ∇fi​(x;Di)∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥subscript𝐷𝑖\nabla f_{i}(x;D_{i}) can potentially reveal information about dataset Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} see discussion in Apeendix E.1.
2. GD [FP16|FP32|FP64]/AES-128 Algorithm 1, Naive usage of AES ( A), 𝒞i​(x)=defxsuperscriptdefsubscript𝒞𝑖𝑥𝑥\mathcal{C}_{i}(x)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}x.

Gradient Descend with symmetric AES encryption which uses a key size of 128128128 bits (161616 bytes). In this algorithm, clients in a distributed way compute the gradient for the function fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} defined in Equation 2 in the current iterate. Then clients encrypt computed ∇fi​(x)∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥\nabla f_{i}(x) in parallel. After that Master collects the encoded gradients as a communication hub. Unfortunately master can not perform any algebraic operations, because ∇fi​(x)∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥\nabla f_{i}(x)are encrypted, and the master needs to broadcast all directions to the clients. The specified Floating-Point format is used to represent both data and trainable variables in all clients and during aggregation in the master. During using AES/EAX there exists a fixed negligible overhead from using EAX Mode Operation Mode of 323232 bytes in each client to master communication information transfer. Specifically, this Mode Operation includes the following overheads: Nonce - a random 161616-byte value, and the Tag - 161616-byte message authentication code.

Quantitative and qualitative characteristics: (1) Master cannot average obtained encrypted clients’ local gradient. (2) Volume information from clients to master is 𝒪​(d​n+32​n)𝒪𝑑𝑛32𝑛\mathcal{O}(dn+32n) bytes per round. (3) Broadcasted information from master to clients is 𝒪​(d​n+32​n)𝒪𝑑𝑛32𝑛\mathcal{O}(dn+32n) bytes per round. For details about AES see Apeendix F.
3. DCGD [FP16|FP32|FP64]/AES-128/RandK Algorithm 1, Naive usage of AES ( A), 𝒞i​(x)=defdk​∑i∈Sxi⋅ei,S∼u.a.r{s:s∈2[d],|s|=k}formulae-sequencesuperscriptdefsubscript𝒞𝑖𝑥𝑑𝑘subscript𝑖𝑆⋅subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑒𝑖subscriptsimilar-toformulae-sequence𝑢𝑎𝑟𝑆conditional-set𝑠formulae-sequence𝑠superscript2delimited-[]𝑑𝑠𝑘\mathcal{C}_{i}(x)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}\frac{d}{k}\sum_{i\in S}x_{i}\cdot e_{i},S\sim_{u.a.r}\{s:s\in 2^{[d]},|s|=k\}.

Distributed Compressed Gradient Descend with symmetric AES encryption which uses a key size of 128128128 bits (161616 bytes), and with using RandK sparsifier. In this algorithm, clients in a distributed way compute the gradient for the function fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} defined in Equation 2 in the current iterate. After this clients compress them by selecting k𝑘k components from d𝑑d u.a.r. Then clients use a sparse bitwise representation of the sparsified gradient and encode non-zero values with AES/EAX mode of operation. Then clients encrypt computed 𝒞​(∇fi​(x))𝒞∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥\mathcal{C}(\nabla f_{i}(x)) in parallel. After that Master collects the encoded gradients as a communication hub. Unfortunately master can not perform any algebraic operations, because ∇fi​(x)∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥\nabla f_{i}(x)are encrypted, and the master needs to broadcast all directions to the clients. The specified Floating-Point format is used to represent both data and trainable variables in all clients and during aggregation in the master. During using AES/EAX there exists a fixed negligible overhead from using EAX Mode Operation Mode of 323232 bytes in each client to master communication information transfer. Specifically, this Mode Operation includes the following overheads: Nonce - a random 161616-byte value, and the Tag - 161616-byte message authentication code. The implementation of RandK sparsifier in the case of using a pseudo-random generator can be implemented in a way that no indices should be transferred during training because they can be reconstituted.

Quantitative and qualitative characteristics: (1) Master cannot average obtained encrypted and compressed clients’ local gradient. (2) Volume information from clients to master is 𝒪​(k​n+32​n)𝒪𝑘𝑛32𝑛\mathcal{O}(kn+32n) bytes per round. (3) Broadcasted information from master to clients is 𝒪​(k​n+32​n)𝒪𝑘𝑛32𝑛\mathcal{O}(kn+32n) bytes per round. (4) Fundamentally there is some redundancy induced by the inability to perform aggregation in the master.
4. GD [FP16|FP32|FP64]/CKKS Algorithm 1, Baseline ( B), 𝒞i​(x)=defxsuperscriptdefsubscript𝒞𝑖𝑥𝑥\mathcal{C}_{i}(x)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}x. Extra encryption is carried via employing CKKS.

In this algorithm, clients in a distributed way compute the gradient for the function fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} defined in Equation 2 in the current iterate. After this each client using the public key in CKKS schema performs encryption of gradient vectors. Master obtains the encoded gradients from the clients. Then master using a public key performs aggregation and relinearization to reduce the size of a ciphertext after arithmetic operations. After this master broadcast aggregated gradient estimator. Clients using private (secret) keys perform for decryption of the encrypted direction from the master and then make a step.

Quantitative and qualitative characteristics: (1) CKKS encryption considerably increases ciphertext space. The volume of information from clients to master 𝒪​(C⋅d​n)𝒪⋅𝐶𝑑𝑛\mathcal{O}(C\cdot dn) bytes, where C𝐶C is a constant which depends on d𝑑d, security level, degree of the used polynomial, and cardinality of space ℤqsubscriptℤ𝑞\mathbb{Z}_{q} to represent integer coefficient of two transferred polynomials after encoding. (2) Size of public and private key to guarantee AES-128 for CKKS is approximately 420 000420000420\,000 bytes, while for AES-128 the key size is 161616 bytes. In some tasks this key size is negligible, in some tasks, it is not. For details see Appendix G. (3) CKKS does not operate on the level of bits only and can operate only with fp64 float point format in TenSeal implementation. Therefore there is no possibility of using less precision in combination with CKKS. For details about CKKS see Appendix G.
5. DCGD [FP16|FP32|FP64]/RandK/CKKS Algorithm 1, Baseline ( B), 𝒞i​(x)=defdk​∑i∈Sxi⋅ei,S∼u.a.r{s:s∈2[d],|s|=k}formulae-sequencesuperscriptdefsubscript𝒞𝑖𝑥𝑑𝑘subscript𝑖𝑆⋅subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑒𝑖subscriptsimilar-toformulae-sequence𝑢𝑎𝑟𝑆conditional-set𝑠formulae-sequence𝑠superscript2delimited-[]𝑑𝑠𝑘\mathcal{C}_{i}(x)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}\frac{d}{k}\sum_{i\in S}x_{i}\cdot e_{i},S\sim_{u.a.r}\{s:s\in 2^{[d]},|s|=k\}. Extra encryption is carried via employing CKKS.

Distributed Compressed Gradient Descend with CKKS. In this algorithm, clients in a distributed way compute the gradient for the function fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} defined in Equation 2 in the current iterate. After this clients compress them by selecting k𝑘k components from d𝑑d u.a.r. After this each client using the public key in CKKS schema performs encryption of sparsified gradient vectors. Master obtains the encoded gradients from the clients. Then master using a public key performs aggregation and relinearization to reduce the size of a ciphertext after arithmetic operations. After this master broadcast aggregated gradient estimator. Clients using private (secret) keys perform for decryption of the encrypted direction from the master and then make a step.

Quantitative and qualitative characteristics: (1) CKKS encryption considerably increases ciphertext space. The volume of information from clients to master 𝒪​(C⋅d​n)𝒪⋅𝐶𝑑𝑛\mathcal{O}(C\cdot dn), where C𝐶C is a big constant which depends on d𝑑d, security level, degree of the used polynomial, and cardinality of space ℤqsubscriptℤ𝑞\mathbb{Z}_{q} to represent integer coefficient of two transferred polynomials after encoding. For details see Appendix G. (2) Size of public and private key to guarantee AES-128 for CKKS is approximately 420 000420000420\,000 bytes, while for AES-128 the key size is 161616 bytes. In some tasks this key size is negligible, in some tasks, it is not. For details see Appendix G. (3) CKKS does not operate on the level of bits only and can operate only with fp64 float point format in TenSeal implementation. Therefore there is no possibility of using less precision in combination with CKKS. (4) The CKKS does not support linear operations over sparse vectors from ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}. For HE schemas, encoding of any two vectors (e.g. sparse and dense) should be indistinguishable due to semantic security requirements. However, from a computational perspective, ignoring sparsity is sometimes highly impractical. This gap presents an open research question for HE.
6. DCGD [FP16|FP32|FP64]/PermK/AES Algorithm 3.

Distributed Compressed Gradient Descend with using PermK sparsifier. In this algorithm, clients in a distributed way compute gradients in the current iterate. After this clients compress them by selecting k𝑘k components from d𝑑d jointly via using Algorithm 2. Then clients send a sparse bitwise representation of the sparsified gradient. Master collects the encoded gradients as a communication hub. The PermK compressor garantees that what is needed to perform at master is only concatenation. Therefore the algorithm can be implemented in practice in situations when the master can store, but cannot compute. The specified floating-point format is used to represent both data and trainable variables. The implementation of PermK in the case of using a pseudo-random generator can be implemented in a way, that no indices should be transferred during training because they can be reconstituted and negotiation between clients should be carried in runtime if clients have negotiated initial seed.

Quantitative and qualitative characteristics: (1) There is 323232 byte overhead during message transfers compared to DCGD/RandK. (2) The current implementation works only in case d≥n𝑑𝑛d\geq n, when DCGD/RandK and GD/CKKS do not require this (3) Volume information from clients to master is 𝒪​(d+32​n)𝒪𝑑32𝑛\mathcal{O}(d+32n) bytes per round. (4) Broadcasted information from master to clients is 𝒪​(d+32​n)𝒪𝑑32𝑛\mathcal{O}(d+32n) bytes per round.
7. DCGD [FP16|FP32|FP64]/PermK Algorithm 3 in which E​n​c​r​y​p​t​(x)=defxsuperscriptdef𝐸𝑛𝑐𝑟𝑦𝑝𝑡𝑥𝑥{\color[rgb]{0,0,1}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,1}Encrypt}(x)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}x, D​e​c​r​y​p​t​(x)=defxsuperscriptdef𝐷𝑒𝑐𝑟𝑦𝑝𝑡𝑥𝑥{\color[rgb]{0,0,1}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,1}Decrypt}(x)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}x.

Distributed Compressed Gradient Descend with using PermK sparsifier. In this algorithm, clients in a distributed way compute gradients in the current iterate. After this clients compress them by selecting k𝑘k components from d𝑑d jointly via using Algorithm 2. Then clients send a sparse bitwise representation of the sparsified gradient. Master collects the encoded gradients as a communication hub. The PermK compressor garantees that what is needed to perform at master is only concatenation. Therefore the algorithm can be implemented in practice in situations when the master can store, but cannot compute. The selected floating point format is used to represent both data and trainable variables. The implementation of PermK in case of using a pseudo-random generator can be implemented in a way, that no indices should be transferred during training because they can be reconstituted and negotiation between clients should be carried in runtime if clients have negotiated initial seed.

Quantitative and qualitative characteristics: (1) The current implementation works only in case d≥n𝑑𝑛d\geq n only, when DCGD/RandK and GD/CKKS does not require this. (2) This algorithm ignores privacy and security aspects. (3) Volume information from clients to master is 𝒪​(d+32​n)𝒪𝑑32𝑛\mathcal{O}(d+32n) bytes per round. (4) Broadcasted information from master to clients is 𝒪​(d+32​n)𝒪𝑑32𝑛\mathcal{O}(d+32n) bytes per round.
references: In our work, we made a comparison of several optimization algorithms with different compression and security methods. In Table
below we summarize their qualitative and qualitative features.
